title: 111_s2917
content: The "Small Business Penalty Fairness Act of 2009" limits penalties for failure to disclose reportable transactions based on resulting tax benefits. The penalty for failure to disclose reportable transactions is 75% of the tax decrease shown on the return, with a maximum penalty of $200,000 for listed transactions. The penalty for failure to disclose reportable transactions is $50,000 ($10,000 for a natural person) for any other transaction, with a minimum penalty of $10,000 ($5,000 for a natural person). Effective after December 31, 2006. SEC. 3. REPORT ON TAX SHELTER PENALTIES AND CERTAIN OTHER ENFORCEMENT ACTIONS. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue must submit an annual report to Congress on penalties assessed by the IRS under various provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, including accuracy-related penalties, promoting abusive tax shelters, and failure to furnish or include information on reportable transactions. The annual report to Congress must include information on penalties assessed by the IRS under different provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, such as accuracy-related penalties, promoting abusive tax shelters, and failure to maintain lists of advisees with respect to reportable transactions. The report must also detail actions taken under specific sections of the Code and any extensions of time for tax assessment. The first report is due by June 1, 2010. SEC. 4. Amends Section 6657 of the Internal Revenue Code to apply bad checks penalty to electronic payments. Effective for instruments tendered after enactment. SEC. 5. Applies levy to payments to federal vendors for property. SEC. 5. Amends Section 6331(h)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code to include property, goods, or services for levies approved after the enactment of this Act in 2010. The act aims to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to adjust penalties for failure to disclose reportable transactions and submitting bad checks to the IRS, as well as modify rules for Federal vendors.
